user_request: A poem about a bird that comes down the walk and doesn't know the speaker is watching.
final_poem:
A cardinal, bright as a ribbon pulled from red silk,
lands where the porch railing drops its shadow—
the exact place I was not looking but should have been.
It does not turn. It thinks the stone is part of morning.

From my kitchen window I am just a frame now,
a wooden border on a print the bird has come to read.
Its head tilts left, then right, as if confirming
some sentence it had only half memorized.

I could step outside. I could open the screen door
and let the cardinal jump the span between us,
but something—maybe not fear exactly, more like
the principle of a shutter already closed—keeps me seated.

The bird examines a crack in the mortar.
A single feather lifts from its breast
and rides the cold air the way a word
escapes a mouth before the sentence is finished,

already gone, already lost, already
part of something else. The cardinal
does not move. It has found what it came for—
a small dark shape, a food particle suspended—

while I am studying how light changes
the color of a thing that does not care.
It tilts its head again. It is almost,
very nearly, the way attention bends toward something

that has bent itself to be noticed.

Then it rises—not flapping, more like
a nail unscrewed from thought—and flies
the ten feet to the hydrangea where a sparrow waits,
and they are both inside their own business

as I sit here with the window open wider now,
the room full of the cold, the feeders ringing,
and nothing between us but the bright fact
of what happens when a creature comes down the walk

not knowing it has been named.
